cs.LG, cs.AI, cs.DS, cs.GT, cs.SI. 

The paper deals with a learning problem in which an algorithm needs to make decisions about which arms to play in order to maximize a reward. This is a classic problem in machine learning and falls under the category of reinforcement learning. The paper specifically focuses on the combinatorial multi-armed bandit (CMAB) problem, which is a variant of the multi-armed bandit problem where subsets of arms can be played together. This suggests that the paper could fall under the categories of machine learning (cs.LG), artificial intelligence (cs.AI), and data structures and algorithms (cs.DS). 

The paper also discusses the extension of the CMAB problem to include probabilistically triggered arms, which means that the outcome of one arm can affect the probability of another arm being played. This suggests that the paper could also fall under the categories of game theory (cs.GT) and social and information networks (cs.SI), as these fields often deal with decision-making in complex systems.
